citeinfo.origin: Hazards and Vulnerability Research Institute (HVRI), University of South Carolina
citeinfo.title: Social Vulnerability Index (SoVI) for Virginia based on 2000 Census Block Groups

pubinfo.publish: Hazards and Vulnerability Research Institute (HVRI), University of South Carolina

descript.abstract: This data depicts the social vulnerability of Virginia census block groups to environmental hazards. Data were culled primarily from the 2000 Decennial Census.
descript.purpose: The Social Vulnerability Index (SoVI) measures the social vulnerability of U.S. counties to environmental hazards. The index is a comparative metric that facilitates the examination of the differences in social vulnerability among counties. SoVI is a valuable tool for policy makers and practitioners. It graphically illustrates the geographic variation in social vulnerability. It shows where there is uneven capacity for preparedness and response and where resources might be used most effectively to reduce the pre-existing vulnerability. SoVI also is useful as an indicator in determining the differential recovery from disasters.

idinfo.datacred: Hazards and Vulnerability Research Institute (HVRI), University of South Carolina
idinfo.native: Microsoft Windows XP Version 5.1 (Build 2600) Service Pack 3; ESRI ArcCatalog 9.3.1.3500

dataqual.logic: Standard data quality procedures were followed for compiling the data.
dataqual.complete: Data completeness reflects the contents of the 2000 Census Block Group.

citeinfo.origin: Hazards and Vulnerability Research Institute (HVRI), University of South Carolina
citeinfo.title: The Social Vulnerability Index (SoVI)
citeinfo.othercit: NOAA CSC received this data from another Institution (Hazards and Vulnerability Research Institute(HVRI), University of South Carolina). Questions regarding the original data collection and /or processing should be directed to that agency.

srcinfo.srccontr: Census block group level data on social vulnerability to environmental hazards

procstep.procdesc: Created comparative index of social vulnerability to environmental hazards for census block groups based on socioeconomic and demographic data from the US Census Bureau.
procstep.srcused: Hazards and Vulnerability Research Institute, University of South Carolina
